sub_topic: Calculation of magnetic field due to a straight conductor
message_1: A straight wire of length 20 cm carries a current of 5 A. Calculate the magnetic field at a point 10 cm away from the wire. Given: The permeability of free space is 4π x 10^-7 T m/A.
message_2:
We can use the Biot-Savart Law to calculate the magnetic field at a point due to a current-carrying wire. The formula for the magnetic field (B) at a point P at a distance (r) from a straight wire carrying a current (I) is given by:

B = (μ₀ * I) / (2 * π * r)

where μ₀ is the permeability of free space.

Given:
Length of the wire = 20 cm (not needed for this calculation)
Current (I) = 5 A
Distance (r) = 10 cm = 0.1 m
Permeability of free space (μ₀) = 4π x 10^-7 T m/A

Now, we can plug in the values into the formula:

B = (4π x 10^-7 T m/A * 5 A) / (2 * π * 0.1 m)

The Amperes (A) cancel out, and we can simplify the expression:

B = (4π x 10^-7 T m * 5) / (2 * π * 0.1 m)

B = (2π x 10^-7 T m * 5) / (0.1 m)

B = (10π x 10^-7 T m) / (0.1 m)

B = 10π x 10^-6 T

The magnetic field at a point 10 cm away from the wire is approximately 3.14 x 10^-5 T (Tesla).
